text: But even something like E. coli, it certainly behaves in what we call space, but it's at least not clear to me that it has a representation of space.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Although there are processes in the E. coli that do distinguish, say, the two ends of the E. coli.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: I mean, even if you think of the chemotaxis pathway, the two ends of that pathway are quite distinct functionally.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: So perhaps E. coli has a one-dimensional representation of space.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: It can tell its anterior end from its posterior end.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: but perhaps it doesn't have any representation of what we would call left and right or up and down.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: But if you look at multicellular organisms, even something like, say, hydra,
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: is a spatially quite sophisticated kind of thing.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: I mean, it's not bilateral.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: It's cylindrically symmetrical.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: But it's got a very large distinction between anterior and posterior, and it seems to know quite a bit, at least I understand from people who work on Hydra, about its own body, the state of its own body.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: And so I think these are exactly the same kinds of questions that we should be asking.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: And they also apply at the scale that's much larger than us.

text: And what can that agent represent?
speaker: SPEAKER_05

speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: And I think those questions are all essentially open.

speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: And
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: If you're looking at classical information processing, to the extent that it's not reversible, it requires energy, and so one can immediately derive limits based on the free energy access of that system.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: A colleague and I wrote a paper several years ago called Science Generates Limit Paradoxes.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: And we basically rehearsed a version of this very discussion that we're having right now.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: And the upshot of that paper is that in any situation in which a science can turn its theoretical apparatus onto its own practice,
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: So, for example, when physics can turn this analysis of boundaries onto the practice of physics, then it generates paradoxes.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: And those paradoxes have a particular structure, which is the structure that Priest, I can't remember his first name,
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: a logician who works in non-dialethic logic, calls a limit paradox.

text: But I think this situation really is ubiquitous and inescapable.
speaker: SPEAKER_05
